Reviews.Title: Nikon Coolpix S8200, Great camera with a few design flaws
Reviews.Author: Snoopy1
Reviews.Content: I just received my Nikon Coolpix S8200 so my initial comments are admittedly based on just a couple of days playing with the camera, however I noticed how few comments there were, so I thought prospective buyers of this camera should have some additional feedback on which to base their purchase decision.  First of all, the other reviewers are right about the placement of the flash mechanism.  This is one of the few times that I have had a Nikon camera where so obvious an error in design was made.  I have long fingers and you can learn over time, but it is difficult to hold the camera steady without overlapping the flash.  I didn't however let this feature detract from the other excellent features.  The quality of the pictures are exceptional indoors and out.  I have a Nikon D7000 and the S8200 camera compares favorably in a lot of ways. The mode dial offers choices not on previous Coolpix cameras.  The 14X optical zoom is a major improvement over previous cameras like the P300 and for a compact digital camera, the shutter speed is amazinging fast.  I like that this model is slightly thicker and a little heavier than my old S3000.  It feels better in my hand and I can hold it easier.  I will have no problem traveling with this camera when it is not practical to take my D7000.  I also like the design of the multi-selector putting functions like flash control, self-timer, macro and exposure adjustment convenient so I do not have to go into a menu to use these features. This camera is a little pricey, but if you put a premium on quality and flexibility versus the average compact digital camera, I would suggest you buy this camera. I don't think you will be disappointed.June 2012 Update:  One of the most impressive features of this camera is the quality of indoor shots it takes without a flash. Shots are bright, clear with no artificial light distortions that you see with other non-DSLR cameras. I now almost exclusively take low light shots without the flash unless it is outdoors at night with no additional lighting present. I recently attended an indoor graduation ceremony where flash would have been ineffective at the distance I was from the stage.  I was concerned that the shutter speed would be so slow without flash that would result in blurred images.  This wasn't the case.  Almost all of the shots were clear and lighting was exceptional.

Reviews.Title: great camera, what up with the flash?
Reviews.Author: db
Reviews.Content: I received my Nikon S8200 a few days ago.  It is wonderful; easy to use; fast; and did I say, fast.  The CMOS screen is better than my Nikon SLR.  Downloading the photos to my Nikon Capture NX2 software on my iMac 24" screen results in photos that are nearly as stunning as my Nikon SLR.My only gripe is the flash.  Whoever decided to put the pop-up flash where it is either never uses a point-and-shoot camera or has little bitty toddler-sized hands.  The flash pops up out of the camera right where your left index finger rests.  The first time I used it and the flash was required, the flash never came out fully as my left index finger blocked it.  The photo was lost.Warning for critical photo shoots: if you are hoping to get your child's first step indoors where the flash will be required, be careful, you may loose the shot. You must practice a new way of holding your camera.Page 12 of the supplied manual shows an artist's drawing of the left and right hands properly holding the S8200 camera for flash operation.  What Nikon has shown is physically impossible with normal sized hands and fingers on the 4" wide S8200.My solution modification: I added a small 3/4" x 1/8" felt strip to the top of the flash to give me a tactile-feel reminder of the problem.  This reminds me to reposition my fingers and thumbs before using flash photography.  Now I position my left index finger on the middle of the top of the camera with the left thumb on the middle of the bottom being sure to not block my view of the rear screen with my left hand.  Weird, but it can be done.Someone at Nikon surely thought that the flash on the S8200 was real cool.  No, it is not.  Do the felt strip mod and you will remember to reposition from the norm.

Reviews.Title: Like it a lot. Amazed so far.
Reviews.Author: LittleReadBooks 'n' More "LittleReadBooks 'n'...
Reviews.Content: Just got my S8200 tonight and am still battling a bad cold, so I didn't really have a chance to take photos other than inside my house (primarily of my dogs, bedroom, and small christmas tree.)  But I have to say, I'm pretty impressed.As always, I despise my newest camera and am typically *sure* I'm sending it back for its first 1/2 hour in my hands, until I've had time to get to know it and discover its nuances.  Same thing happened here, not surprisingly.  But now I really love it.I shoot with Nikon SLRs professionally, but I always carry a little 'snappy cam' as I call them, around with me, because you never know what you'll end up wanting or needing a photo of.  I have an 'old' (2006) Nikon S7C which is certainly small enough and easily portable, but the quality is really lacking, especially with video - which is the other reason I bought the s8200.  Full 1080p video is lovely.  Hardly any lens zoom noise or AF noise, which is quite different from the 'clickity click hummm' the S7C makes.I PONDERED long and hard over getting this or the P300.  While I love the idea of the P300s fast 1.8 lens, the P300s zoom range is around 24-100mm, whereas this camera's is 25-300mm, and I really need the zoom more than the fast lens.  Not to mention that once you zoom in, that fast lens slows down considerably, anyway.  And I don't plan to do a lot of night shots with any 'snappy' camera like this.There is another major difference between the two, and that is the S8200 is 16.1MP and the P300 is only 12MP. You will see the difference in enlargements, especially any over 8x10.I did a couple of test shots at the long end of the lens (I turned the defacto  crappy digital zoom off - which is a nice ability, by the way, so that means just the optical 300mm) and I am really wowed at how clear and sharp they came out.  The VR really works well (another thing the old SC7 does have, but that has been clearly improved.)As for all the other features, I believe they are the same on both models (the S8200 and the P300.)  The only difference lies with P300s ability to shoot in program mode, aperture priority, shutter priority, and manual mode.  You know what?  I've been doing this for a long time now, and I don't know a lot of pros who would want or need that much control in a 'snappy' camera.  I can't speak for all pros, but I know the reason many of us carry these is NOT to duplicate and downsize our SLRs, but for the same reason everyone else carries them: to take snapshots!  So if I wanted that much control, I'd just stick with my DSLRs.Took some video (which look great on the beautiful LCD) but haven't had a chance to see any of them on a TV yet.  I can't seem to get them converted so I can view them on Apple TV (iTunes keeps crashing during conversion - my netbook's fault I hope.)  I'll have to convert it on my studio's desktop PC.  The other option is direct plug-in, but I only have 1 HDMI input on my bedroom tv and don't feel like contorting myself to plug the camera in directly.  So I'll have to wait and upate my review about the quality of the video once I'm well enough.Things that I am surprised I like:* the black and white copy (not sure why it's called 'copy' - I will have to RTFM)  Update: I did RTFM, and it turns out it's for making copies of print materials.  Despite what it's intended use is, I liked the way some of the photos I took with is came out (that were not printed materials.)* the high-contrast monochrome,* the backlighting mode with the ability to choose 0, 1, 2, or 3 stops of HDR (it does the work of compositing in-camera, and you get one nicely-exposed HDR image.)  Would love an HDR button on all my cameras, actually, LOL.* the flash - this little thing throws out a lot of light.  I got excellent coverage on a Xmas tree ornament 10 feet away with the lens at 300mm.Things I don't like:* the cheap plasticky door for the HDMI/USB connection.  I prefer rubbery ones.  These don't make me feel like they'll last a lifetime.* the lack of a manual. Yeah, can't believe I'm crabbing about it since I don't read them much, but apparently, I miss them.  Thankfully, I have my PC handy.* the fact that you cannot push the flash back in once it's been used.  So let's say the first photo I take needs a flash but all the rest that follow do not.  Thanks to Nikon I'll still have the stupid flash popped up and in my way.  The only way to retract the flash is to turn off the camera and then turn the camera back on to start snapping again.  Stupid design.  I'm sure they'll fix it in some later model at which point my S8200 will appear on eBay.  LOL.* the fact that it doesn't come with any - ANY - carrying case.  Even the S7C did. (not that I ever used it.)If they remedied the above shortcomings, and if it had a tilt/swivel LCD for shooting at low/high angles, as well as the ability to shoot RAW for optional post-processing futzing*, it would be the perfect camera, IMO.*While I said I don't want to miniaturize my DSLRs in a snappy cam, I do want the option of post-processing any excellent photo that I may grab while snapping.  RAW is the best way to do that as the changes you make to the file are non-destructive...as opposed to JPEG.

Reviews.Title: The point & shoot I was waiting for!
Reviews.Author: Peggy H
Reviews.Content: After much research online, I chose this camera.  Which unfortunately for me, was only 2 weeks before my vacation to Spain.  I received my camera 1 week before my trip, which gave me no time to really practice with it beforehand.  So I downloaded the 228 page manual and took it with me!  Note to Nikon:  Print a book!  I would have paid more just to get it!  I am in love with this camera!  The low light performance is outstanding, as is the image stabilization and macro shooting.  I only used the video a couple of times, but the shooting is easy,and something I will use in the future.  I am a previous Nikon customer, so the controls were easy to figure out without having to study my manual.As a previous user had stated, the flash design is awkward.  It took a couple of days of using it before I stopped putting my finger on top of the flash.  I started using one hand to take the photos, and they were still extremely sharp.I can't wait to choose my photos for enlarging & framing.  At 16 MP, the sky's the limit!

Reviews.Title: Disappointed
Reviews.Author: genesis
Reviews.Content: i liked the specs on paper for the S8200, while the images look good viewed on screen, inspecting them at 100% view reveals noise and heavy processing specially in dim/dark areas of the image.The AF in bright light is very fast, but struggles in dimmer lighting, even with the AF assist. Many times, it just refused to lock.I have an S8100 and the S8100's images are much cleaner even when viewed at 100% and the AF locks MUCH better even in low light (although in the S8100, there is an annoying delay after the AF lock which is very prevalent specially in low light)Other weird items:1. annoying pop-up flash that can't be pushed down manually, but can be disabled by turning flash off. problem is, to retract theflash, you need to turn off the camera2. unable to turn off image review3. loud beep for button presses. you can turn it off or on but nothing in between4. pet mode selection on dial? huh? night portrait should be more usefulgood stuff:1. the 25mm lens is nice, much better than the S8100 30mm wide.2. charging port is now on the side3. tripod socket is closer to the centerbottom line is IQ is worse compared to the 12MP S8100.

Reviews.Title: Amazing
Reviews.Author: MRB
Reviews.Content: How long did I agonize before picking a camera? A loooong time. I do this everytime. Read all the reviews, look at prices, finally give up and buy one. Well folks, I bought a Sony DSC-Tx7, and a Panasonic DMC-ZS7. Both, in my opinion were not worth the money. The zoom on the Sony..weak. Images in low light were pathetic and all had a yellow sheen that even photoshop would not fix. The daytime and landscape photos were excellent. The Panasonic was a better camera, but again low light photos were over or under exposed. The zoom is excellent. Scene modes were excellent. Enter the Nikon. Simply put: WOW. I dont know what the negative raters are seeing but I have a camera with a powerful zoom, AMAZING low light photos, equally good HD movie (although it is sensitive to low light, as all are) and reasonable shutter lag. Only annoyances: Why does the flash pop up and then can not be reduced without powering off? Seriously...no plugin charger???...how cheap. But all in all I am so impressed by this camera, I have not used my d5000 much, and that is saying something. Stop looking and buy this camera!

Reviews.Title: Better than my DSLR
Reviews.Author: lloydnsher
Reviews.Content: I bought the Nikon S8200 as a pocket camera and backup for my Olympus E-500 DSLR. I did some side by side shot comparisons and was amazed at the image quality of the Nikon.  Out- door shooting the Nikon blew the doors off the DSLR.  Indoors it was a close second and only then when magnifying the image 200% were the pixals more noticeable in the Nikon images. I've heard of people having focus issues with Nikons, but so far haven't seen that... shot recovery is very fast....update april 10 2012.After using the camera for 5 months i'm still very happy with this camera. the backlighting mode is great for indoor shots around windows and lights, and the night landscape mode makes still shots at night look as good as sunlight shots...my only issue so far is occasional white balance problems (too yellow or too blue)...they can be fixed in photoshop but i wish there was an adjustment...my DSLR has the same issue but there is an adjustment on it. Macro mode much better then my dslr...still no problems with focus...99% in focus...video is beautiful...color rich and very clear..

Reviews.Title: Easy to use,and talented
Reviews.Author: BBox
Reviews.Content: Well now, I am very impressed. Selecting a camera from almost entirely online info was not my favorite thing to do. Looks like I hit a home-run. This dynamite little package does all the work, I don't need to concentrate on what settings I am using, it computes most of that for me. Unlike the Olympus and Sony that I had before, this point and shoot does exactely what I need and when. I am most impressed by it's ability to perform in low light situations.Although I have only had it a week, I am very pleased and will reccommend it to my peers. It's very obvious that a lot of thought went into this puppy during R&D.I; love the large LCD screen, and already have used that amazing zoom ability. This is a winner!

Reviews.Title: very happy
Reviews.Author: Ari Goldberg
Reviews.Content: I just took a bunch of test pics with the camera, and I was very pleasantly surprised.  My last camera was stolen - a Canon Powershot SD780-IS point and shoot camera with rounded edges that fit nicely in my pocket.  I had always wanted more zoom, and also hopefully better low-light performance, like at concerts, and I was willing to sacrifice some of the small form-factor of the Canon to get it.So this time around I went with the Nikon S8200.  The Nikon is small enough to go in my front jeans pocket - it doesn't have a lot of protrusions and bumpy parts - it's near rectangle.  It does a great job in low lighting.  I dimmed the lights and turned the flash off and took some pics.  The shutter does something strange - it seems to activate (click) more, and there's a long hour-glass waiting symbol after a low-light picture.  But the results are outstanding - very true to the natural appearance of the room, and no blurriness.All the pictures were great and in focus.  Someone in their review had complained about the auto-focus not locking sometimes, but I found that that happened only in close-ups, and if I switched to macro mode, they became sharp again.  I found that between those two modes, I can cover almost any distance and still have the auto-focus work right.  I really like it so far.I agree with folks that it's annoying for the pop-up flash to to retract until you turn it off.  They should have added a latch that closes it when you press it down.  My work-around is to just turn off the flash and press the flash down into the camera body with my finger.

Reviews.Title: fingers crossed
Reviews.Author: dtodj
Reviews.Content: ordered the S8200 after reading the reviews about the S8100 hopefully Nikon has made the improvements especially "lens error message"zoom was increased screen is clear and bright. menu easy to navigate, flash has a tendency to pop up in moderate low light, I just set flash to off. I use this as a back up to the Nikon L120, easy to slide into pocket. So far battery life is good only problem you have to charge battery in camera so a small separate wall charger is a help, with extra battery. So far so good. Keep up the good work Nikon, sharp pictures -easy to use-good options-good feel-good price.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera for the Money
Reviews.Author: Rasta
Reviews.Content: I have owned this camera for almost a month.  The verdict = Well worth the money.Took camera on Thanksgiving Vacation, it performed and beat my expectations.  When compared to my last camera, the low light performance was great.  Notice I said "low light" and not "no light"  I have seen reviews where consumers expect cameras to perform as if they have night vision built in.Some Pros:* Very fast, but make sure you have a fast SD card or there will be some writing lag with the large file size.* Panoramic shots are very easy!!! Just aim and turn.* Lots of special modes for your picture needs.* Hi def video quality is good.Some Cons:* I hate to jump on the band wagon, but I too agree the flash placement is flawed.  I am surprised at the design* While the panoramic shots are easy, the quality is less than the standard pictures. (I have only used the 180 deg shot)* I wish the battery charger was separate from the camera.  This will allow charging a second battery without needing the camera or having to purchase a separate battery charger.

Reviews.Title: Decent Camera, But Auto Focus Problems!
Reviews.Author: M. A. Blouin
Reviews.Content: I have read all the reviews of cameras in this category on Amazon and others like CNET and Digital Photography review to name a couple. I even tried many at the stores. Previously I owned a Canon, and I liked it, but thought I'd look at the competition. I had it narrowed down to the Canon SX230 (disliked the feel and the widescreen), Sony HX7V, Nikon s9100 and Nikon s8200. I did not include the popular Panasonic in this category, simply because I do not like Panasonic cameras. I tested all but the Nikon S8200 at the store, just to see how it felt, speed etc. I liked the Nikon S9100 the best. Then I read their was a newer model, the Nikon S8200. I read about focus problems with the Nikon S9100, but figured the S8200 would have improved upon that. I decided to order it. Here is what I liked and did not like:LIKE:- It felt really good in the hands, especially for a small compact.- It shot pictures fairly quick (but sometimes it lagged, because of the auto focus problems)- Pretty good indoor photos- Zoom worked well, and was fairly quick- Photo quality of the pictures overall very goodDON'T LIKE:- Auto Focus constantly did not work, which was very frustrating, because often times I couldn't even take a picture.- The video was not so good with auto focus and zooming. The video would always be blurred when zooming and then slow to auto focus- The battery life was a bit low, plus it had to be charged in the camera (but I knew this already)In the end, I decided to return the Nikon S8200 camera, mainly because of the auto focus issues. It just would not lock on! It was so frustrating. I have since bought a Sony HX7V, which is great as of right now. The Sony has much better video and Panorama pictures. However, the Sony is slower than the Nikon S8200. I thought the picture quality was pretty similar on both cameras.

Reviews.Title: Nice night landscape pictures
Reviews.Author: Pink
Reviews.Content: It was a hard decision between the Nikon S9100 and this Nikon S8200.  The 9100 advantage is: longer zoom 18X and the flash is manual release and push down.  The 8200 has 14X zoom and annoying auto pop up flash that can't be pushed down when you are done with the flash. The only way to push the flash down is to turn off the camera.  The only advantage sold me on the S8200 is the image stabilization better than the S9100.  We used the 8200 to take lots of night pictures with holiday lights and downtown skylight in the Night Landscape mode and auto scene select mode.  They came out great, very clear, no blur.  We use a Lexar class 6 SD card, which is the minimum speed recommended by Nikon.  The night pictures were taken at the highest resolution 16M and it took several seconds to save the image.  It's a long wait before you can take the next picture.  The day time pictures seem a bit over exposed and color is a bit washed out in auto mode.  Maybe we need to adjust the brightness and color manually with the dial.  The battery only last one day, about 150 - 200 pictures.  The battery meter ½ mark doesn't mean the batter is ½ full.  It's actually a lot less then ½ full.  For traveling, we definitely need to carry a back up battery.  All in all, we like the picture quality and ease of use.  It's not a 5 star because the annoying pop up flash, the position of the record button, the over exposed day light, battery charging through camera.

Reviews.Title: Sup with the flash??
Reviews.Author: Charles J. Sugarman
Reviews.Content: Just received my Nikon S8200 today.  There are tons of features on this camera, some of which I may never use but it's nice to have them.  I read some reviews about the camera before purchasing it, the most frequent complaint of which related to the auto flash.  It is located right where your left index finger normally rests on the top left surface of the camera and the flash pops up into your finger.  It's kind of annoying and makes me wonder why Nikon designed it that way.  Additionally, you can't push the flash back down manually. You must shut the camera off completely which automatically retracts the flash.  Then you have to turn the camera back on.  Weird!!  The other thing that is lacking is a hard copy of the User Manual.  It comes with a very brief "Quick Start" manual and a disk to download the big manual but no hard copy to carry with you.  The disk is printable but a book would be nice. Otherwise it's a beautiful piece, seems solid and well made and I'm looking forward to a lot of good use.

Reviews.Title: Great shots and full of features
Reviews.Author: marketingmaven
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for my wife as a Christmas gift this year. She loved it.We started on Christmas day with just normal "auto-mode" pictures but didn't get into the features yet. The quality of the basic images is great, clear and crisp! I noticed the zoom and clarity with zoom totally blew away the old Canon we had (granted that had 3x zoom and 7 megapixals), hence the upgrade. BUT, I want to know what this thing can really do beyond normal mode... I decided to read the manual. This little camera is PACKED FULL of features.We took it to the botanical gardens to see how the Macro mode would work and it was amazing. On the viewing screen, the picture looked crisp and clean, and they continue to look just as great (if not even better) once I got them on my laptop screen. I can even see seedlings on the petals of the flowers! How detailed! I was amazed. I even tried a shot at a flower from 20 feet away and with the quality of this zoom, you would swear I took it from 2 inches away! The landscape mode it like any other camera, but I swear the colors are just more vibrant and real. I even used the effects mode which I never touched on any other came... that's kind of fun when shooting foliage, so you can take out everything but green or everything but the red... very cool. I love this thing so far... so does my wife, although it seems its in my hands more then hers :)The main reason for buying this camera was for clear shots at concerts and night settings. Our old camera was terrible in these situations and I am praying this does better. I will update after I test that.Update Jan 17, 2012:Have still not had a chance to use the camera in a concert setting, but have used it in night settings. For the ball drop on new year's the camera took awesome pictures! Great in night light and great with the zoom even in the dark. I will update again when we have had a chance to use it in a concert type of setting.

Reviews.Title: Nikon just a name?
Reviews.Author: JAM115
Reviews.Content: I purchased the S8200 as a Christmas gift to myself intending to use it during the Christmas holidays.  I found the picture quality, ease of operation, video quality and sound quality all to be very satisfactory for a simple point and shoot camera at that price point.  However it really has an overall "in hand" feel that is cheap.  Not what you expect from a Nikon.  I used it for 3 days during Christmas and overall was satisfied with the picture and video results but I did find some problems with the auto focus.  Very slow at times and often would not focus at all. On day 3 the camera's lens system failed.  It would no longer retract nor would it focus. I returned it to the store from which I purchased it with the intention of exchanging it. However as I talked to the store clerk I found that the lens problem is not uncommon for Nikon coolpix cameras he even said that one he purchased had the same issue.  I replaced it with another brand which has comparable specifications at a slightly lower price.  I'm afraid that this might be a case of Nikon living off their reputation and extensive marketing.  I have owned several Nikon film cameras in the past and always liked them for both their performance and quality.  This seems not to be the case for this line of digital cameras.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera! Great Price!
Reviews.Author: E. Schell
Reviews.Content: This camera fulfills every expectation I had for it: small/compact, light, easy to use, powerful zoom (optical and digital) and macro/close-up functions as well, plus a good range of easily accessible exposure settings. I used it on a trip to London recently, and got outstanding photos of everything from the Christmas lights on Regent Street and family gatherings to gorgeous sunsets and incredible movies shot in a bar where my nephew was engaged in a boxing match. In every one of those examples the results far exceeded my expectations. Plus, the price can't be beat, either. I had considered one of the new compact changeable lens cameras at twice the price, but can't imagine having gotten better results than I did with the S8200. And it would have been bulkier than the Coolpix.Obviously, it helps to read the User Manual, which I certainly did. Not everything is intuitive, and I haven't mastered it all yet (for example, I found out the hard way that "no flash" is overridden when you choose the "backlight" setting: intuitive for most, but not at that moment for me. Oh, well...).Being so satisfied with what I have been able to do with this camera, I'm sure it will only get better (for use of the "soft focus" and other special effects, for instance). Tried the "continuous" stills mode for the fight, with good results, but haven't tried the panorama function yet. Didn't feel I needed to. The only people who might not like this camera are those who want to fiddle with their own f-stops, etc. to override the auto settings and do everything manually, or those who truly want just point-and-shoot and nothing else. But if you're the latter, you probably wouldn't be looking at this camera anyway (actually, your smartphone should handle all those kinds of photos). And even for those folks, you don't HAVE to do anything to get great results. The AUTO setting makes this an excellent point-and-shoot that fits in your jacket or pants pocket if that's all you want, and you just might find yourself gradually getting more adventurous in spite of yourself....

Reviews.Title: Very pleased so far
Reviews.Author: P. Scott ""Mr. Practical""
Reviews.Content: I picked up and tested many cameras before I chose the Nikon S8200.  I must admit that I am partial to the Nikon brand - my wife has a D3100 DSLR and my three daughters each have a Coolpix camera.  And they've had no troubles.  I am replacing a dual-lens Kodak V610 which has always been poor in low-light conditions.Here is what I like about the S8200:1. the zoom capabilities are really good for a little camera2. it has proven thus far to be good in low light situations3. easily packable, can slip in my side pocket4. the easy panorama and panorama assist modes are nice for those "big" outdoor landscape shots5. I can easily control the exposure levels6. 1080p video recordingThe one thing I don't like - the pop-up flash.  I had to train myself to place my left index finger at the center-top of the camera or my finger would prevent the flash from "opening."  And to retract the flash the camera must be turned off.  With that said - it took just 1 day of "shooting" to train myself.I look forward to putting the camera to the test in very low-light conditions.I like this camera.

Reviews.Title: Broke after 4 months...
Reviews.Author: CCC
Reviews.Content: I was pleased with the camera initially and thought it produced reliable, sharp pictures.However after about 4 months of use (a 3-4 school functions, and 1 Europe trip), the camera stopped being able to take pictures.  I sent it back to Nikon, who did not honor their 1 year warranty.  They claimed there was "impact damage" that voided the warranty.  I do not remember any "impact damage", and have owned several Canon cameras over the years without this problem.  I was surprised and very disappointed they would not honor their warranty, despite calling their customer service center several times, and speaking with one of their managers.I definitely would not buy this camera again, nor would I recommend it. (...and I will probably go with Canon or  Sony next time!)

Reviews.Title: good camera with some of flaws
Reviews.Author: Ozgur Bozkurt "ozzie"
Reviews.Content: I was going back and forth between canon 510hs  and nikon 8200 and eventually got this camera to replace my old panasonic lumix. The image quality is amazing!!!  the zoom is also great.  It has been only a few days though; I will update my review after I use this camera for a month.There are a few problems with the design.  1- flash pops out from the upper left corner. However, It does not come out the moment the camera is turned on. Instead, it comes out when the camera detects low light.  That causes a problem when you are holding the camera from that corner. 2- you can not charge the darn battery outside the camera - this is also very annoying.  The charger is a tiny unit and the cable is very short.  So I have to put the camera on the floor close to the power outlet  :( 3- it feels like cheaply built ... or cheap components are used ...I would have given 5 stars but the location of the flash and the way that the camera is charged are very annoying. What have you done nikon?  Were your designers asleep?

Reviews.Title: Not Perfect but Close
Reviews.Author: Zman299
Reviews.Content: It's been a week of back & forth camera tinkering/computer pdfing to learn the abilities of this camera and I'm impressed.  Some will call the pdf file for the user manual cheap and I agree, saving me a little more money for the final product.  The videos and photos are so great that I have to rate the camera 5 stars even after experiencing the bothersome pop-up flash that requires you to turn off the camera power to make it retract.  Unless I was a professional photographer, I can't imagine needing more camera for photos and videos than this little gem.  Charging the camera by computer while you are transferring files is nice, but I think I'll be opting for another battery and non-usb charger.  Watching recordings on tv via HDMI or the provided cables uses a lot of power and the camera must be turned off when recharging.  If you're not familiar with backlighting you're going to love it.  We've been getting sub-standard pictures when we have our living room window as a background for years.  I'm not losing image to background brightness any more.  Using setting 2, the target image colors are all there.

Reviews.Title: Very happy with this purchase--photos have been excellent so far!
Reviews.Author: Beth Cholette "doctor_beth"
Reviews.Content: This past Christmas (2011), my husband and I decided that a new camera would be our gift to each other to replace our old Kodak EasyShare system.  Since I am the main photographer in the family, I thoroughly researched available options.  When I say "photographer," I am using the term lightly--while I love taking photographs, always document major events, do some minor photo editing, and do spend some time making albums/scrapbooks as well, I am by no means an expert or even an "amateur" photographer.  Therefore, I was looking for a quality camera that would take excellent photos, but one that would do most of the work for me rather than require me to fool with a lot of settings myself.  The one feature that was particularly important to me was a superior zoom lens, which is part of what attracted me to this model.Overall, I have been very satisfied with the Nikon S8200.  I am probably most pleased with the zoom lens, which captures shots of amazing quality, particularly in comparison to my previous camera.  Another feature that I unexpectedly love is the "Selective Color" option, which allows you to take a photo highlighting a single color (for example, the red of a rose against black & white).  You can also change photos to black and white or sepia right on the camera, and there are plenty of other great shooting options such as continuous burst and best shot selector.  Finally, if you are someone who DOES like to fiddle with settings, you definitely can--EVERY single setting on this camera allows for individual adjustments to the user's specifications.Several other reviewers have mentioned that the placement of the flash on the camera is a problem, especially since it pops up.  Yes, the placement is a bit awkward, but because it pops up when you are focusing, you DO have time to move your hand out of the way before actually taking the photo, so I haven't found this to be a problem.  What I DON'T like, however, is that the only way to reset the flash to the "down" position is to turn the camera off.There are a few other things that I don't like about this camera as well.  For me, these issues are quite minor, but I am mentioning them in case they might be important to others.-->If I take a vertical (portrait) photo, the camera displays the photo in the same orientation, whereas my previous, older camera re-adjusted the orientation manually (e.g., so that all photos faced the same direction when the camera was held upright).-->The camera has two different SCENE settings.  For one, the user chooses the scenes manually (choices include "Food," Party/indoor," "Sports," "Snow," and 10 others), but for the other SCENE selection, the camera choose the appropriate scene.  However, this is just confusing to me--which is better?  Do I choose?  Do I let the camera choose?-->At first, I was finding that the camera was having a second or two of lag time in transferring photos to the memory card (especially in low light), but that was when I was using my old 1 GB memory card.  So, I purchased a new Lexar Professional 16GB SDHC 133x Class 10 Flash Memory Card, and since then, I have not experienced any further speed issues.Again, none of these things have been major concerns for me; at most, they might bring down my rating of the camera to about 4 1/2 stars.  Still, I would highly recommend this Nikon, especially for casual photographers like myself.  If you do purchase this camera, I would also recommend the Must Have Accessories Bundle Kit For Nikon Coolpix.  This is worth it just for the extra battery and charger (neither of which come with the camera), but you also get several other nice bonus items, include a very good case and a USB converter.

Reviews.Title: Overheated in Video mode, froze scrolling through images
Reviews.Author: harrobwil
Reviews.Content: I returned Nikon Coolpix S8200 camera mainly because when in play mode it would lock-up when scrolling through (still) pictures that I had taken. The only way I could correct was to remove and re-install the battery. It also overheated during video recording and stopped recording. The manual warns of this but I did not expect it to occur so quickly. I returned the camera and received a full refund from Amazon. I then purchased (from Amazon) a Lumix ZS20, now I get wonderful pictures, wonderful zoom, wonderful HD video (including zooming while recording).

Reviews.Title: Not impressed any more
Reviews.Author: Ron Smith "LG80827"
Reviews.Content: When we originally received this camera was impressed but now after several months not at all.  The battery dies all the time even having just charged it.  Will take one or two pictures and then won't.  Shuts it self off when trying to view pictures.  Now unable to take any pictures at all as it will not stay on long enough.  When you turn it on nothing shows on screen.Would not buy this camera again.

Reviews.Title: Incredible photos from a point and shoot
Reviews.Author: R Moskovitz
Reviews.Content: I recently took this camera on a photo safari in South Africa. I was intimidated, at first, by my fellow travelers with huge SLR's. By the end of the trip, however, my photos competed well with theirs. The 14X optical zoom captured most of the wildlife visible with the naked eye. And even small images blew up with exceptional detail when edited on my laptop. Other photos that were too dark, such as landscapes taken at dusk, revealed exquisite details when shadows and highlights were removed. I captured a number of prize shots while my more elaborately equipped co-travelers fiddled with lenses or settings. Video quality was also excellent.  In the end, I was delighted with the convenience and versatility of this small camera. Even our guide was impressed with its capabilities. The only advantage of the larger cameras was the capability of shooting birds on the wing. This was hampered both by the limitations of the LCD screen vs the viewfinders of the SLR's and by the delay between the button press and the shot. That limitation notwithstanding, the S8200 will remain my travel camera of choice.

Reviews.Title: Great camera...until it broke for no reason
Reviews.Author: Travis B.
Reviews.Content: *PLEASE READ BEFORE BUYING THIS CAMERA*Let me start this off by saying, this camera took great pictures and has AMAZING zoom/picture quality. It's easy to use and has a lot of cool features, and great quality HD video too.That being said, the low star review is due to the camera just stopped working suddenly and would not come back on. I work in IT for a living, so I troubleshoot technology on a daily basis. I tried a different battery and charge cables, allowed the device sufficient time to charge, but the display would not come on, and the lens would sometimes extend out like it was on, sometimes not; the display was "lighting up", but nothing on the screen, just black. Camera just DIED. It was my wife's favorite camera, so she was heartbroken. It was within the standard one-year manufacturer's warranty, so I called in a service order with Nikon. It was surprisingly easy how quickly they generated a case and had me send them my camera. In fact, it was a little too easy. So I pay $10 to have it FedEx'd to a Nikon repair center in New York. The camera was promptly returned to me within 3-4 days, stating only "no repair - not a U.S. product" on the return invoice. Wow...GREAT...now what?So I hopped online and started chatting with amazon customer service. I explained the situation, and how disappointed I was for amazon selling me the camera knowing I would never get service for it; and I was especially disappointed since my wife truly loved the camera while it worked. So the amazon rep takes a few moments and, after some "words", I got them to process a refund for me. So I ship the camera back, and today (10/11/13), I see my refund invoice in my email...AMAZON CHARGED ME A $42 RESTOCKING FEE FOR THIS STUPID CAMERA! WOW!!!Avoid buying this from any of these goofball retailers and verify it is a U.S. product - if not, you'll be HOSED. Bottom line, Nikon AND Amazon dropped the ball on this and screwed me out of $52 and my valuable time. Basically, you should probably just avoid nikon if they just give customers the shaft life this.Oh and to top it off...I ordered a different camera and my wife hates it...GREAT....here comes another restocking fee.

Reviews.Title: Nikon Of Course
Reviews.Author: himself711
Reviews.Content: From Nikon, you expect a premium piece of equipment. That is what you  have here; the S8200 is easy to operate, takes real nice pics & has a 14x optical zoom& 16 megapix. What more can you say... Before buying, I compared some other models, i.e. the S9100, but felt the S8200 was a better overall buy for me, even though the S9100 has a longer zoom, but less megapix. Also, I looked at Canon & Panasonic; to me the Nikon was the better buy in similar price range...

Reviews.Title: Everything I was looking for
Reviews.Author: sn4x
Reviews.Content: Just took this camera to London, Paris and Amsterdam and it was awesome!  Great shots without a flash.  Camera includes a panorama setting that was a pleasant surprise when reading the manual since it was not listed on the specs.  This was the third camera that I purchased.  First purchased the Nikon 9100, returned because most of the pictures were blurry. Then tried the Sony DHC-H70 and was very disappointed with its low quality.  Spent a little more on this Nikon than the Sony and it is completely worth it.  I can't say it enough, this camera is a great point and shoot.

Reviews.Title: Lens issues
Reviews.Author: Crystal Ann Crown "Crystal"
Reviews.Content: I got this camera less than a week ago and I've gone through two of them. Within a few days of getting the first one the zoom function started acting funny. The first few days the pictures were great, the camera focused very fast and the images were clear, even when zoomed in fully-- my only complaint is that the battery ran out rather fast. Then, it started sounding a little funny when I would zoom in, a sort of grating noise that I hadn't noticed before, and the camera's ability to focus when zoomed in completely failed.I exchanged it this evening for another one, figuring that I got a lemon. I played with it a bit, started taking pictures in different modes to see that it was working properly and the same thing started happening again. First the autofocus when zoomed in wasn't working, then it wouldn't focus at all, even when fully zoomed out, and now the lens is completely stuck and won't retract into the camera at all and I get a "lens error" message when I turn it on-- or rather, that's what happened when the power button was still functioning... I can't even get the thing to turn on as of 5 minutes ago. So, within 5 hours this camera went from seemingly working fine to being completely unable to focus and mechanically a failure. I did nothing more than take it out of the box, put the battery and memory card in, and start shooting. Total disappointment, especially after seeing that most of the other reviews were awesome. I obviously won't be exchanging this for a third of the same model...

Reviews.Title: Much searching and finally bought it!
Reviews.Author: Audrey
Reviews.Content: I absolutely love my camera! After much comparison with the nikon S9300, I chose the S8200. Yes the 9300 had more zoom quality but its something that I didn't need and after all the other bad reviews of it being unreliable and not flashing fast enough I went with the S8200 even though many reviews stated they didn't like the flash popping up under your finger. Well I have not stopped taking video and pictures with my new nikon. The pictures come out very clear and amazing. The video is a point and shoot feature that I love and is in HD. This camera has the ability to change different megapixles from 16.1 and below. Why you would want to do that is beyond me but its there! I chose to use an San Disk Extreme 16gb. It allows thousand of pictures in 16.1mp and multiple 30 min video. If you want longer video time I suggest getting a 32 or 64gb san disk. This disk will make all the difference trust me! This camera is filled with lots of neat things as well! The flash popping up under the finger doesn't bother me but it might for someone with larger fingers. It is also something you can train your hand to not do while taking photos.All in all, I love my Nikon camera and I'm extremely happy with my purchase.

Reviews.Title: Great camera, battery let down
Reviews.Author: S. Ram
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera in February 2012 for a trip to India. The photos were absolutely fantastic. This camera was especially amazing because if you've ever been to India, the air is very, very dusty. This camera did a great job getting past focusing on the dust and grabbing a beautiful picture. A major downside is the flash though. It pops up right where your finger would naturally lay on top of the camera.Now my biggest pet peeve is I used this camera for only two weeks. TWO WEEKS. I fully charged the battery and tried to use the camera again last week. My camera either refused to turn on or would turn on for a few seconds to show me I had a fully charged battery, but then say "battery exhausted." After reading hundreds of reviews online, this seems to be a HUGE defect of the camera that Nikon refuses to acknowledge. People are being forced to ship the camera back at their own expense only to be told it needs a new battery and the camera is fine. If this is the case, Nikon owes ever Nikon owner a new, FIXED battery at THEIR expense.

Reviews.Title: I'll never buy an Olympus again
Reviews.Author: Sarah
Reviews.Content: This take absolutely beautiful pictures. The zoom is incredible. Great image stabilizing. I take a lot of action shots and I need something that can deal with that in moderate light. I've had point-and-shoot and DLSR Olympus cameras and they just can't compare to this lil guy. I don't mind the pop-up zoom, it takes one second to turn the flash off anyway.

Reviews.Title: Superb Camera
Reviews.Author: Ramesh Kasarla
Reviews.Content: This camera quality is really very good. The video is also excellent, it is HD.  Zoom & lens work as advertised. Most of the Blurs/Red Eye's will not be seen.This is a user friendly camera, easy to operate and  you can download to your PC or laptop easily.Disadvantages:-1. Flash comes up when you take pics.2. No Touch Screen

Reviews.Title: Great portable camera
Reviews.Author: Lori.K
Reviews.Content: We were looking for an upgrade to our Canon Powershot SD980 which was not that great to begin with.  Was much happier with our older Canon Powershot which had much better performance in low light but for some reason our silver model didn't last a year, had problems with the focus TWICE.  Gave my parents the same model in black and it's still working.So glad my husband bought the Nikon S8200 before a trip to California. Great camera for travel. He was leaning towards an SLR at first but I'm very happy with this camera. Great pictures even in low light. Good zoom. We may end up getting an SLR at some point but this is a camera that I can bring anywhere with ease.The only drawback was the flash location as other reviewers have mentioned, hopefully it doesn't break.

Reviews.Title: Great point and shoot!
Reviews.Author: TBark2013
Reviews.Content: This is a great point and shoot camera! I got it for Christmas so I've only had it for a couple of weeks but it has been great. I've tried it out in a lot of low light situations and tried all of the different modes and it has been fantastic. It has the sweep panorama which is awesome and it seems like all of the pictures are in high definition. I am extremely pleased with the pictures and transferring them to the computer is really easy. If you're looking for a solid point and shoot in this price range, look no further. The s8200 is the camera you're looking for!

Reviews.Title: Many great points, some significant flaws
Reviews.Author: Templet "templet"
Reviews.Content: There's lots of praise in the reviews for the camera's many strong features, so let me dig into the problems I'm having that are potential deal breakers.Others have reported focusing problems, and I have experienced them also. Usually I can achieve proper focus by just making a small change in the zoom setting. But not always.As one might expect from such a long zoom lens, distortion at the edge of images can be pretty bad, particularly at wide zoom angles. There's no workaround for this.Maybe my biggest complaint is dynamic range. This really shows up in contrasty images. Crushing the highlights is not unusual in digital cameras and can usually be tolerated because it doesn't bother the rest of the image. Not so in the s8200. Take a picture of a car in bright sunlight. You'll see bothersome flare around every point of strong sunlight reflection. I just took a picture of a scene with some fairly dark trees surrounding a light slate roof. I could put up with crushing the detail in the roof, but there's a big bloom area that extends far beyond the roof. This just should not be in a decently implemented moderately priced camera. I can reduce the bloom to relatively small proportions by cutting exposure down to the -2.0 limit, but then most of the rest of the photo is too dark. When I take the same photo with my wife's canon s100, the bloom isn't there.I was prepared to like this camera for its features, but the image and focusing defects are making me think I'll return it.

Reviews.Title: Very happy
Reviews.Author: Bk
Reviews.Content: I had this camera only for three weeks. I have taken pictures of my grand kids playing soccer and pictures of friends and relatives at my brother's Birthday party. Pictures are sharp and vivid. I highly recommend this simple to use camera.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera
Reviews.Author: sanfrantreat
Reviews.Content: After using this camera for about 3 weeks I had great success with it. Selective color options were great and the image clarity was awesome! This camera re Ives 4 stars not only cause you can use selective color with video but the images are awesome and clear. My only drawback was that after 3 weeks I was left really wanting more from my pictures, and it's fine for face book and suck but really clear dslr quality photos was what I was after. This camera is great for people who are on the go looking to nab those candid and priceless moments, as start up to shooting was super fast. If you need a camera for all interesting deals and moments this is it. I'm a clothing designer and the photos of my clothing and color replication need to be nothing short of amazing. I'm glad I tested it out though because for an automatic ps. It's a real killer.

Reviews.Title: So far, it's AWESOME
Reviews.Author: Tara
Reviews.Content: I have only had the camera for 1 week, but I have been super impressed with it so far.  I love the sports theme because it takes multiple pictures of the subject.  I was able to get pictures of my son's entire baseball swing.  The only downside is that I took 400 pictures for one baseball game, that I later had to go through.  The pet setting is also great, no green eyed pets in pictures any longer.  The long zoom on this camera is great.  I was able to take pictures of kids in the outfield while I was still in the stands at my son's baseball game.  The clarity of the pictures is also fantastic.  I completely recommend this product, based on my limited experience with it.

Reviews.Title: Nikon S8200 better than comparable Sony Camera
Reviews.Author: Di G. "Di G."
Reviews.Content: I was looking for a camera that would be small in size so that I could tuck it in my purse and go.  I have another Nikon that I just love but the size is larger and would never fit in my purse.I first purchased a Sony camera that had the capability to manually select settings; it was a touch more expensive than the Nikon.  Other than that the features were almost identical to the Nikon S8200.  My first inclination was to go with the Nikon because of past experience with Nikon cameras but I thought I'd give the Sony a try because of the added features.I played around with the Sony camera trying out the different settings.  I was not totally pleased and I had some blurred photos that should not have been blurred.  I have been a photography buff for over 30 years so I know what type of photos I should be getting.  Since I had 90 days to return the camera to the place of purchase without penalty, I was glad that I took my time.  About a month and a half into the 90 days, I purchased the Nikon S8200 from the same place so that I could do multiple side-by-side comparisons.I tried all of the settings on both cameras.  I wasn't totally comfortable with not being able to push down the flash on the Nikon as I could on the Sony and have it stay down.  My way to work around that is to just push down the flash and hold it with my finger if I don't want to use the flash despite what the camera is telling me.  Problem solved.  What finally sold me on the Nikon and made me return the Sony camera was when I took photos of some roses in a vase in my kitchen.  I took many photos with both cameras and tried every setting on each camera.  In every photo I took with the Sony I never was able to capture the true color of the roses.  They were either washed out or the color was more vivid than they were in real life.  The roses were a pinkish orange.  With the Sony they appeared as a vivid orange.  When I took the same photos with the Nikon under the same lighting conditions and using all of the settings on the camera just to experiment, the color of the roses in the photos were right on.  That sold me on the camera.I knew in my heart that I should have gone with the Nikon from Day One but I thought I'd try the other one out. Over this past weekend I used the camera extensively for a birthday party and for photos before a school dance with 12 couples as the subjects.  The photos came out very nice for both affairs.  I know that I will be very pleased with this camera for the long run and I have no intention of returning it to the store where I purchased it.  I just purchased another Nikon model camera for my daughter's birthday present as well.  I anticipate being a life-long Nikon user.

Reviews.Title: Nikon Coolpix S8200, can't complain.
Reviews.Author: JavierBenitez
Reviews.Content: I got this camera weeks ago, and now I am reviewing it after giving use to it. And I must say, this camera works perfectly. It has a lot of great features, the quality of the photos and videos are superb. The only complain is the sounds of the videos, it has this weird noise. But other than that, I am very pleased with it.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: D. Steen
Reviews.Content: I have owned several digital cameras over the years, and this is my first experience with Nikon.  I have always bought Kodak Easyshare cameras because I have the printer dock.  I did a lot of research to find the best affordable digital camera that would take good indoor pictures.  I got to use my camera for the first time this weekend in the Pocono Mountains, and I was thrilled.  It was so easy to use since I basically let it do everything automatically for me.  It took excellent pictures outside in the snow and inside the house.  The flash that pops up is a little awkward since I keep forgetting to move my left hand out of the way, but it is something that I will get used to, and since the flash works so good I won't complain too much.  The camera itself feels very sturdy and looks like it can take a few bumps.  I have not used the video feature yet since I have a separate video camera.  I like that when I turn it on, it is warmed up and ready to go almost instantly.  I am very happy with my purchase and can't wait to use it again.

Reviews.Title: Evaluation of the Nikon Coolpix S8200
Reviews.Author: ATK
Reviews.Content: I am extremely please overall with this camera.  The clarity and quality of picture is amazing and the location of all of the controls on the camera is easily within reach.  The only thing that I still have to get use to is where the flash is located.  The flash pops up on the top left corner which is where your hand normally is.  One will have to put their left hand on the side of the camera or you will block the flash.  Otherwise, the intensity of the flash is much better than other small digital cameras I have seen.I highly recommend this camera and for the price, you can't go wrong.

Reviews.Title: Great camera with one problem
Reviews.Author: another buyer
Reviews.Content: I must say I really like this camera. It's got great features and takes great pictures. Only flaw is the flash. The flash pops out of the top left corner. I am use to holding camera on that corner. So now I have to change my hand position. Even with that flaw I still give the camera 5 stars. It's great!

Reviews.Title: AMAZING CAMERAA
Reviews.Author: ANON
Reviews.Content: This camera takes amazing pictures i loved it!!!! The zoom can take clear pictures from a couple hundred feet away and looks just as good as close up pictures.  Also the pet mode option is pretty great because my dog always moves when i try to get a picture and this takes three pictures at once so you get a good shot.  I would recommend buying this camera great buy

Reviews.Title: I LOVE IT, BUT...
Reviews.Author: Stoney
Reviews.Content: the S8200 is a classic "camel"---a horse designed by a committee. It is brilliantly engineered, and loaded with terrific features. The overall ergonomic design and layout of the controls is marvelous---but the assignment of functions to those controls, and the organization of the features, was VERY poorly thought-out and poorly implemented. Many features have misleading names and some are redundant. Incredibly, (incredibly stupidly) the most valuable, most advanced, features such as "High Dynamic Range" and "Noise Reduction" (both of which combine bursts of photos for improved sharpness or shadow/highlight detail) and others are ONLY available in the "Basic" (or "Scenes") mode where the user does NOT have access to the wide range of useful (even essential) features which are available in the "Advanced" (or "Auto") mode. That makes for a great deal of frustration and a steep learning curve."AUTO SCENE" MODE NOT ADEQUATELY IDENTIFIEDThe "Auto-Scene" mode is indicated on the "modes dial" by a little heart. It is probably overlooked by the very users who would most benefit from using it. In fact, this is the most-"Basic" mode, for users who do not want to learn to use the advanced features. It would be better as the first option in the "Scenes" mode."CONTINUOUS" MODE MISNAMED AND REDUNDANTThe so-called "Continuous" MODE (which is different from "Movie" mode) is in fact the (most) "Advanced" mode in this camera. It includes ALL the menus, features, and options of the "Auto" mode, plus the various "Continuous" FEATURES which includes the options of 5-shot bursts, "Best Shot Selection", and "Pre-Shooting Cache", and more. The "Continuous" FEATURES should be an sub-menu in the "Auto" mode menu (with the addition of an "off" or "single shot" option), and the "Continuous Mode" should be eliminated.UNNECESSARY RESTRICTIONS OF OPTIONS IN "SCENE" MODEAt first glance, the "scenes" in the "Scene" mode look like helpful options, even for advanced users. They aren't---they are sour fruit---because you loose access to nearly every function, option, or setting which are available in the "Advanced" (or "Auto") mode. In most cases, you can't even turn the flash on or off. Unless you carry around the 228-page "Coolpix S8200 Manual" with you, you have no idea what the pre-selected, fixed, features and settings correspond to any particular "scene" (overriding any settings you made in the "Advanced" [aka "Auto"] mode)."HELP" IS UNHELPFULThe so-called "Help" is unhelpful. If you select "Help" with a "scene", it describes what the "scene" is (which is pretty much self-explanatory anyway), such as "Portrait is for portraits", "Landscapes is for landscapes", "Sports is for sports", "Sunset is for sunsets", etc. but it does NOT tell you which pre-determined, fixed, features the camera will use for those "scenes". For example, it would be helpful if the "Help" mentioned that the "Skin softening" function is automatically used in the "Portrait" mode. Or, it might be helpful to know that in the "Museum scene" the flash is turned off, and the camera is set to "Best Shot Selection" mode.There is no "Help" to explain functions, options, or settings. For example, there is no "Help" to explain what "HDR", "BSS" or "Low Key" are, or how to use "Selective Color" or "Easy Panorama".NO CONTROL OF CONTRASTSometimes the dynamic range (difference between the blackest blacks and whitest whites) is too great, requiring reduction of the contrast, or you may want to increase the contrast of cloudy-day photos. Unfortunately, there is no "contrast" feature. You can adjust the "brightness", but that's not the same as "contrast".The "vividness" feature can be used adjusts saturation (the intensity of color)--but that is NOT the same thing as "contrast".The "High Dynamic Range" function (which, in effect, reduces contrast) is available only in the "Backlighting" mode, but if you choose "Backlighting" mode, you loose access to nearly every function, option, or setting which are available in the "Advanced" (i.e., "Auto") mode.HIGH DYNAMIC RANGE POORLY IMPLEMENTEDThe "High Dynamic Range" function takes a burst of photos and combines them into a single photo, in effect, reducing the contrast. Most advanced digital cameras will take a burst of photos at slightly different exposures which can be combined to produce a higher dynamic range, under the control of the user--the result is finely detailed photos with detail both in the darkest shadows (if desired) and in the brightest highlights (if desired). In the S8200, the crippled HDR feature is hidden in a single mode ("Backlighting"), and the user has only the choice of three levels. The entire burst should be saved (but isn't), so that post-photo processing can be used.NO BRACKETING FUNCTION"Bracketing" (i.e., a "burst" function which takes 5 or so photos at different exposures) is a popular function available in all "professional" digital cameras. Logically, "Bracketing" could be combined with the "High Dynamic Range" function---i.e., if the HDR burst was saved, those would (de facto) be bracketed exposures."AUTO FOCUS" FUNCTION MISNAMEDALL of the 6 focusing functions are "auto". There is NO "manual focus" in the traditional photographic sense. The "Auto" focus option, under "AF Area" function is in fact the "focus on the closest object" option. Many users are likely to mistakenly assume that "Auto" is the best general purpose setting--it isn't, although it is useful in some circumstances."CENTER" FOCUS REDUNDANTWhen you choose misnamed "Manual" focus, the display actually begins in "Center" focus mode-you have to tap on the "OK" button to change to "Manual" focus. "Manual" focus allows you to move the focusing bracket. If you tap the "OK" button after moving the focusing bracket, the bracket freezes at the location, then you can use the selector wheel and "OK" button to select the "Brightness", Hue, or "Vividness" functions--a good design. What's need is a "reset" (say, by "double-clicking" the "OK" button, to recenter the focusing bracket.YOU CANNOT CANCEL THE POPUP FLASH BY SIMPLY PUSHING THE FLASH DOWNI can cancel the pop-up flash for the next photo by simply pushing it back down on my Nikon 8100, which was very convenient---but for some silly reason that is forbidden on the 8200. It's annoying that you have to turn the camera off to retract the flash. As others have noted, the location of the flash is where your left index finger wants to be. However a 1" x 3/16" length of self-adhesive "velcro" over the "flash" hatch, can remind you to keep your index finger back out of the way.CLUTTERED "MODE" DIALThere should only be two "photo-taking" modes: "Basic" and "Advanced", whatever they are called. The name "Auto" mode (for the "Advanced" picture-taking mode) is acceptable for consistency with more advanced cameras which have actual manual modes. However, in this camera, "Auto" is confusing since there are four (4!) other arbitrary "automatic" picture-taking modes available on the "mode dial": "Continuous", "Scenes", "Auto-Scene" and "Effects". "Movie" mode (the 6th picture-taking mode) is inexplicably available via a different button. In addition, the dial is cluttered the misnamed "Night Landscape", "Backlighting", and "Pet Portrait" modes which are really just "scenes" which should logically be accessed from the menu of the "Scenes" mode.The "Advanced" modes, "Auto", "Continuous", and "Effects" should be combined in the "Auto" mode. The "Basic" modes ("Scenes" and "Auto-Scene") should be combined as the "Scenes" mode. "Setup", "Playback" (at least the various editing and copying functions) and "Movie" could logically be the other modes accessed on the "modes dial"."SETUP" AND "IMAGE MODE" UNNECESSARILY CLUTTER EVERY MENUThe misnamed "Image Mode" (i.e., the "resolution") would be more logically placed in the "Setup" menu (only). "Setup" (or "Setup/Settings") would be better as a mode in the "mode dial" rather than cluttering-up EVERY menu the camera displays.NO CONTROL OF DEPTH-OF-FIELDThe Nikon 8200 can take excellent closeups, even from 20 feet (or more, or less) away, which makes it ideal for nature lovers, but with one glaring shortcoming. There is no control over depth-of-field. Indeed, according to the specifications (pg 6) the aperture has only 2 positions f3.3 and f6.6 (at the widest zoom), although you don't have a choice even there. F6.6 at the shortest focal length (wide zoom) may translate into about f11 at long focal lengths (telephoto zoom), for a little more depth-of-focus. At the other extreme, in true portraits you usually want the background to be blurry. F3.3 (at widest zoom) probably translates to about f5.6 at a semi-telephoto zoom appropriate for portraits, which is probably will NOT sufficiently blur the background."EFFECTS" MODE MENU POORLY DESIGNEDBesides the misnamed "Image Mode" (i.e., resolution, which really should be in the "Setup"/"Settings" menu), the ONLY option in the "Effects" mode menu is the "Special Effects" submenu. There are only 6 effects, all which could be listed on the basic "Effects" menu---the sub-menu is a wasted step. The entire submenu should be moved to the "Advanced" ("Auto") mode menu, and the "Effects mode" eliminated."EASY" PANORAMA UNNECESSARILY RESTRICTIVE"Easy Panorama" can only be used at the widest zoom position, and only for a "width" of 180 or 360 degrees. I can see times I might want to take a panorama at a semi-telephoto zoom for 90 degrees, for example, but that option is not available."MAGNIFY" AVAILABLE ONLY IN "PLAYBACK" MODEA "quick-magnify" function accessed by a "push to magnify" button, which would magnify the area of the focusing brackets would be very useful, to confirm the focus, particularly in closeup photography, however, there is no way to magnify a portion of the screen while in a "picture-taking" mode.NO "BLACK AND WHITE" FUNCTIONThere's a "Sepia" function (brown and white), and even a "High-contrast monochrome" function (for photographic white boards, text, etc.) but no (normal contrast) "Black and White" function. You can get "black and white" by setting the "vividness" function to zero--but how many users will know that?VOICE MEMO LIMITEDYou can only add a voice memo to an existing picture, by turning off the camera, and selecting "Voice Memo" from the "Playback" menu. A much better design would be a simple "push to record" button which would add a memo to the last-taken photo when in "picture-taking" mode, or to the "selected" photo in "Playback" mode."QUICK RETOUCH" AND "D-LIGHTING" NOT RECOMMENDED"Quick Retouch" and "D-lighting" in the "Playback" menu make copies of existing photos, enhancing the contrast, brightness, and saturation of the copy. I suspect that many users will make copies of the copies to further "pop-up" their photos. However, "if it ain't there, you can't enhance it". That is, if the highlights are so bright that detail is washed out (lost), or shadows are so dark that detail is lost, it CANNOT be recovered. Alot can be done with a proper photo-editing program and a big computer monitor (to see the detail), but on the small camera screen, these functions are more likely to damage an image than improve it. A useable "High Dynamic Range" feature would be far more useful.DESCRIPTION OF "CLOSEUP" SCENE OPTION WRONGAccording to the "Coolpix 8200 Reference Manual", page 47, "Macro mode is enable and the camera automatically zooms to the closest position at which it can focus". In fact the "Closeup" scene option sets the focus to "continuous" operation, NOT to the closest position.JPEG ONLYThe 8200 save images in the JPEG format only, with a minimum compression of 4X. JPEG always degrades the image.  Why not LZW (lossless) TIFF or even RAW?  Sure they take up more memory space, but memory is cheap these days.NEEDS AN EXTRA BATTERYThe battery holds a good charge, but, especially taking alot of video, in "Disneyland" or at the "Grand Canyon", you can drain the battery pretty quickly. The ideal solution is to have an extra charged battery handy. Fortunately they are cheap.  High Capacity 1050 mAH EN-EL12 Replacement Lithium-Ion Battery for Nikon CoolPix S620 S6100 S9100 S8100 S8000 S6000 S1100pjEXTERNAL CHARGER RECOMMENDEDFor a ridiculous $8 (incl shipping at the time of this writting) you can get a AC/DC (car) charger, with two (2!) spare batteries--so that you can keep shooting while charging batteries in your car or hotel room.  TWO EN-EL12 Replacement Battery + Battery Charger FOR Nikon CoolPix S1000pj / S610 / S610c / S620 / S630 / S640 / S70 / S710 / S8000 Digital CameraNEEDS A CASEThe "official" leather case (currently out of stock so Amazon won't let me insert a link) is terrific if you wear it from a belt, or keep it on your desk, but not so much otherwise.  Unfortunately, it holds only the camera--you need another case for accessories.  There is room for a "spare battery compartment" to the right of the lens, but no such compartment. There is a "spare memory card" compartment---but using it risks scratching the viewing screen.  But that's a good place for a piece of paper with your name, address, and phone---in case you loose the camera and it is found by the right person.  It is important to protect the battery contacts from shorting-out when not in the camera.  A tiny ziplock bag (e.g., such as small jewelry comes in) works well, as does blue painters tape ScotchBlue Painter's Tape for Multi-Surfaces 2090-.75A, 3/4 Inches by 60 Yards, 1 Roll The case looks good worn from an inexpensive black "military" belt, even over a skirt or pants without belt-loops.  Army Camouflage or Solid Color Military Web BeltsDOES NOT NEED A NECK CORDA neck cord such as COSMOS 5 pcs Black Long Neck Strap Band Lanyard (36 inch full round length)For Camera Cell phone ipod mp3 mp4 PSP Wiimote ID card badge and other Electronic Devices + Cosmos cable tie sounds like a good idea in many circumstances.  However, using a neckcord for a few hours resulted in the display of my camera becoming badly scratched by swinging against my plastic shirt buttons.NEEDS A TRIPOD OR MONOPODThe S8200 has such a sensitive sensor and such effective image stabilization that hand-held long-telephoto photos can be sharp. The problem is that it is hard to frame a long-telephoto photo hand-holding, and it is impossible to tell if the camera is actually focusing on your subject.  Most tripods or monopods are so bulky that they defeat the whole purpose of such a compact camera.  However, I've found that the tiny Norazza TD140 monopod dies the job providing the necessary stability to make the most use of the incredible telephoto abilities of this camera.  Norazza Monopod-lightweight TD140COOLPIX S8200 MANUAL (available as a pdf file only) IS NOT "COMMENTABLE"So, for example, even you have Adobe Acrobat or other tools, you cannot even highlight or underline a sentence to remind yourself of an important point. If you find an error, such as discussed above, you are forbidden to add a note to the text (for your own personal use) correcting the error. You cannot even copy portions of text, to make yourself a shortened "manual" of the features you use most.

Reviews.Title: Great
Reviews.Author: GIOVANNI BOJORQUEZ
Reviews.Content: This is a great option for an snapshot camera, great zoom, and quality image, the back LCD is really big, and the battery last enough time, the only issue is that you charge the battery direct to the camera

Reviews.Title: Finally Found the Perfect Camera
Reviews.Author: Rosalyn K. Taylor "rktaylor"
Reviews.Content: I love this camera!  I had three Canons, the last being the S95.  I spent hours taking out red-eye from almost every picture that was taken with the S95.  So I decided to try Nikon this time.  I am glad I did!  I have had very few pictures with red-eye in them!  Most are when you use the zoom option.  The S95 has too many bells and whistles, and I wanted a camera I could turn on and take a picture, and this one fit the bill!  The options are buried deep down in the S95, and I didn't like having to get out the manual every time I took pictures.  The Nikon 8200 has the best options right on the camera dials. Easy!  The zoom is awesome, and looks just as clear as taking them without the zoom.  I was used to the flash pop-up from the S95.  I just move my finger, and if it bothers me, I turn it off and back on.  That takes a couple of seconds. The HD video looks and sounds great.  'Record' is a separate button on the camera, and you don't have to move the dial.  The camera does go black for a second when you push Record, so be ready a second before you start recording.  The battery life is good, too.  I take a lot of pictures, and have only had to charge it twice in two months.  I prefer having an extra charged battery on hand, so I bought a kit with an extra battery and a wall charger in it.  I couldn't believe the price; it is well worth the money.

Reviews.Title: Very Disapointed - Not a Good Product
Reviews.Author: Juan, PTY
Reviews.Content: I recently purchased this camera to have a compact camera with an aceptable images, I had read thru some comments here in amazon.com that some problems with the lens and zoom have been detected with this model, but having a look to the samples pictures I decided to go and purchase. That was a terrible error, just with a few pics taken the lens start giving a lens error message, then some noise of the motor of the lens, and then never started again.That was very frustrating since I have been a Canon user, and with my first Nikon one - I really think never to go back with Nikon. I have had more than 10 compacts between Panasonic Lumix, Canon and Olympus and never saw a very low quality gear like this one.Really the pictures are quite good, but this flash in that place and having problems so quickly with an almost new camera is a real disaster.What about the support in the web page:Why does  my camera show "lens error" on the screen?Having a "Lens error" message display on the camera's LCD display indicates a problem with the camera lens mechanism. This situation generally requires that the camera be sent to a Nikon Service Department for repair. Before doing this however, be sure to check these situations below:  One possible reason for this error is if the camera is switched on and the lens unit is prevented from extending.  The camera will struggle for a second to extend the lens, then report the problem. Inspect the lens for any obvious obstruction,  then turn the camera off, then on again. Usually, simply switching the camera Off then On again is enough to correct this problem.  Remove and recharge the battery. Retest.If this does not help, then we regret the camera must be sent to our Nikon Service department as there are no user serviceable parts on Nikon Coolpix cameras.To find your local Nikon authorized service agent Click Here.We apologize for the inconvenience and will do everything we can to repair your Nikon camera as quickly as possible.If Nikon knows to have a factory problem, they should recall and stop selling this piece of trouble. Dont waste your money.

Reviews.Title: Ticked all the boxes
Reviews.Author: Runner
Reviews.Content: I am an art conservator and was looking for a new camera to take pictures of projects as well as your everyday type shots of dogs doing silly things, vacation snaps etc, plus I wanted something small enough to fit in a bag. For my work I need a good macro that can take an extreme closeup of a chip in white porcelain. Many camera's have a hard time reading that, they can't distinguish between the chipped part of the porcelain and the non-damaged area. I took a chipped white bowl to a camera shop and played with a number of camera's before playing with this one. The camera shop did not have this in stock but fortunately Amazon did. I have been very pleased at the quality of the images it takes, plus it fits into my handbag so I can take it on jobs or vacation without weighing myself down with all the heft of an DSLR. It's an easy to use, intuitive camera. My only complaint is the same complaint I read about while researching this camera, when the flash pops up you have to turn the camera off to push the flash away. The other issue is the flimsy feeling USB cover. Neither issue was a deal breaker since it was the picture quality and particularly the ability of the macro that sold me.

Reviews.Title: A very good point & shoot
Reviews.Author: S. Ostrander "budgetqueen"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to take pictures at a flower show when my D5000 was in for repair.  It did a great job. There are some challenges in focusing close-up but if you look at your indicators and follow the guidelines in the manual (which I didn't at first) you won't have a problem.  Pictures are sharp and the colors are good.  My fellow photographers were impressed with the depth of field produced.  For those who don't want to charge the battery in the camera there are 3rd party chargers available that are very inexpensive.  I really enjoyed shooting with this camera.

Reviews.Title: Perfect...
Reviews.Author: R.D.
